questions.text: Multiparous pregnancy predisposes to all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pre-eclampsia Pre-eclampsia, characterized by hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation, is more commonly associated with primiparous (first-time) pregnancies rather than multiparous pregnancies. While multiparous women can still develop pre-eclampsia, the risk is generally lower compared to first-time mothers unless there are additional risk factors such as advanced maternal age, preexisting hypertension, or diabetes. This makes pre-eclampsia the exception among the conditions listed as being predisposed by multiparous pregnancy. Why Other Options Are Incorrect (A) Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH): PPH is a well-known risk in multiparous pregnancies due to uterine atony, which is more common in women who have had multiple pregnancies. The repeated stretching of the uterus can reduce its contractile ability, leading to an increased risk of hemorrhage after delivery. (C) Anemia: Anemia is a frequent complication in multiparous women due to the cumulative nutritional demands of multiple pregnancies and inadequate recovery time between pregnancies. Iron deficiency is particularly common, especially in women with insufficient dietary intake or postpartum bleeding. (D) Malpresentation: Multiparous pregnancies are associated with a higher risk of malpresentation, such as breech or transverse lie, due to laxity of the uterine and abdominal muscles from previous pregnancies. This can lead to improper fetal positioning as the pregnancy progresse

questions.text: Optimum interval between uterine incision and delivery of fetal head during cesarean secton should be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 90 seconds The optimal interval between uterine incision and delivery of the fetal head during a cesarean section is approximately 90 seconds. This timing minimizes the risk of complications for both the mother and the baby. Prolonged intervals may increase the risk of fetal hypoxia, as the fetus relies on placental oxygenation until delivery. A delay beyond 90 seconds could lead to uteroplacental insufficiency, particularly in cases where uterine contractions or maternal hemodynamic factors compromise blood flow. Additionally, maternal surgical risks such as increased bleeding and uterine trauma may arise if delivery is unnecessarily prolonged. Thus, a swift yet controlled extraction of the fetus is ideal. Anesthesia: Regional (spinal/epidural) is preferred, with a T4 dermatome level required for adequate anesthesia. • Incision: Pfannenstiel for the skin and low transverse for the uterus are the most common. • Antibiotics: Administer cefazolin within 60 minutes before incision to prevent infection, adjusted for allergies or prolonged procedures.

choices.text: Most common pituitary tumor but rarely symptomatic
Increase in prolactin levels worse prognosis
Macroadenoma>1 cm is associated with bad prognosis

questions.text: Prolactinoma in pregnancy, all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Serum prolactin levels serve little use because of normal rises during pregnancy hence cannot be use for determining prognosis of tumor A microadenoma is ≤10 mm, and a macroadenoma is >10 mm. suprasellar macroadenomas have tumor enlargement that causes visual disturbances, headaches, and diabetes insipidus. most recommend treatment is surgical resection before pregnancy is attempted Hence associated with bad prognosis Pregnant women with microadenomas should be queried regularly for headaches and visual symptoms. Those with macroadenomas are followed more closely and have visual field testing during each trimester. (Ref Williams obstetrics/25th edition/1132 )

questions.text: A 25-Year-old primigravida with 20 weeks of pregnancy has a first episode of a symptomatic bacteriuria. The risk of having pyelonephritis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 25% Pyelonephritis is a serious upper urinary tract infection that can occur during pregnancy, often due to untreated or inadequately treated bacteriuria. Pregnant women with symptomatic bacteriuria have a significantly higher risk of developing pyelonephritis compared to the general population due to the physiological changes of pregnancy, such as ureteral dilation, urinary stasis, and immune modulation. If bacteriuria is left untreated or not effectively managed, the risk of progression to pyelonephritis is approximately 25% in such cases. Pyelonephritis during pregnancy can lead to complications such as preterm labor, low birth weight, and maternal sepsis, highlighting the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Regarding antibiotic of choice for urinary tract infection (UTI) during pregnancy at third trimester:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cephalosporin Cephalosporins are considered the antibiotic of choice for treating urinary tract infections (UTIs) during pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester. These antibiotics are generally safe for use during pregnancy and have a broad spectrum of activity against common UTI pathogens such as Escherichia coli. Cephalosporins are well-tolerated and effectively treat UTIs while minimizing the risk of harm to the developing fetus. They do not cross the placenta in significant amounts and are less likely to cause teratogenic effects compared to other classes of antibiotics. For these reasons, they are preferred during pregnancy. Why Other Options Are Incorrect (B) Quinolones: Quinolones (fluoroquinolones), such as ciprofloxacin, are contraindicated during pregnancy because they are associated with potential fetal harm, including cartilage damage and tendon toxicity. These medications can cross the placenta and may affect fetal development, making them unsuitable for treating UTIs in pregnant women. (C) Aminoglycosides: Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin, are also generally avoided during pregnancy due to their potential to cause nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity in the fetus. Although they may be used in life-threatening infections when other options are unavailable, their use is carefully restricted in pregnant women. (D) Tetracyclines: Tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline) are contraindicated during pregnancy because they can cause permanent discoloration of the teeth in the developing fetus, as well as possible effects on bone growth. They also cross the placenta and pose a risk of teratogenicity, making them unsuitable for treating UTIs during pregnancy.

questions.text: All can be used to lower mother to child HIV spread except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) has outlined a comprehensive PPTCT program aimed at reducing HIV transmission from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding. 1. Goals of the PPTCT Program • Eliminate new HIV infections among children. • Reduce the transmission rate of HIV from mother to child to <5%. • Improve maternal and child health outcomes. Key Interventions Early HIV Testing • All pregnant women are tested for HIV during their antenatal visits using rapid HIV diagnostic tests. • Partner testing is encouraged for a comprehensive approach. Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) • For HIV-positive mothers: • Lifelong triple-drug ART (TLD regimen): Tenofovir (TDF), Lamivudine (3TC), and Dolutegravir (DTG). • Started as early as possible in pregnancy, regardless of CD4 count or clinical stage. • For newborns: • Nevirapine (NVP) prophylaxis for all HIV-exposed infants: • 4-6 weeks of NVP if the mother’s viral load is controlled. • Extended NVP for up to 12 weeks if the mother’s viral suppression is inadequate or breastfeeding continues. Vaginal delivery is preferred mode and CS done for obstetric Indications. Avoid invasive procedures, ARM, instrumental delivery. Infant Feeding • Exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months is recommended, followed by complementary feeding while continuing ART. • Avoid mixed feeding as it increases the risk of HIV transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of fibroid in pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Maternal Complications During Pregnancy: • Pain and Degeneration: • Red degeneration (necrobiosis) due to rapid growth and compromised blood supply. • Presents with acute abdominal pain, low-grade fever, and tenderness over the fibroid. • Miscarriage: • Submucosal fibroids increase the risk of early pregnancy loss. • Placental Abnormalities: • Placental abruption(more characteristic) or placenta previa( less common) due to abnormal implantation. • Preterm Labor: • Uterine irritability or reduced space in the uterine cavity. • Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR): • Large fibroids may compromise placental blood flow. • Polyhydramnios or Oligohydramnios: • Distortion of the uterine cavity can affect amniotic fluid dynamics. During Delivery: • Obstructed Labor: • Cervical or lower uterine fibroids may obstruct the birth canal. • Malpresentation: • Fibroids can distort the uterine cavity, leading to breech or transverse lie. • Uterine Atony: • Impaired contraction of the uterine muscle increases the risk of postpartum hemorrhage. • Cesarean Delivery: • Increased likelihood due to labor complications or fibroid location. Postpartum: • Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH): • Suboptimal uterine contractions (atony) due to fibroids. • Infection: • Increased risk of postpartum endometritis.

questions.text: Which female genital malignancy is most common in pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cervical Cancer Cervical cancer is the most common female genital malignancy in pregnancy. It is often diagnosed during routine prenatal screening, such as the Pap smear, or when patients present with abnormal bleeding or pelvic pain. Although the incidence of cervical cancer is relatively low during pregnancy, it is the most frequently encountered genital malignancy during this time. The human papillomavirus (HPV), a known risk factor for cervical cancer, is prevalent in the sexually active population, making cervical cancer a more common malignancy in women of reproductive age, including during pregnancy. Treatment options for cervical cancer during pregnancy depend on the stage of the disease, but early-stage cancers can often be managed with minimal disruption to the pregnancy.

questions.text: In a pregnant woman of 28 weeks gestation IUD is earliest demonstrated on x0ray by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Signs of IUD detected on xray are : • Appearance of gas shadow (Robert’s sign) in the chambers of the heart and great vessels may appear as early as 12 hours • Spaldings sign :- The irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another is due to liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault. It usually appears 7 days after death Other findings are : • Hyperflexion of the spine is more common. In some cases hyperextension of the neck is seen. • Crowding of the ribs shadow with loss of normal parallelism. Hence answer here is option D

questions.text: Intrauterine death at 36 weeks. Treatment is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In about 80% of cases, spontaneous expulsion occurs within 2 weeks of death INDICATIONS OF EARLY INTERFERENCE • Psychological upset of the patient • Manifestations of uterine infection? • Tendency of prolongation of pregnancy beyond 2 weeks ? • Falling fibrinogen level (rare) Induction if at all required is always done with medical methods Place of cesarean section in a case with IUD is limited. Previous cesarean section (two or more), major degree placenta previa and transverse lie are the rare conditions. Hysterectomy is never indicated in patients with IUD

questions.text: A G2P1 at 36 weeks of gestation has a H/O prior stili birth at 37 weeks. The best time of delivery for the patient this me is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The overall risk of recurrence of stillbirth varies between 0% and 8% since the incidence of recurrence is very less pregnancy should be continued for as long as possible hence answer here will be option D 39 weeks ( ref dutta textbook of obstetrics/8th edition/378)
